awd_titl_txt: Time-dependent Density-Functional Approaches for Excitons: Linear Response Versus Real Time
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division jointly fund this award on fundamental research and education to develop theoretical and computational methodology for the study of light-matter interactions in semiconducting and insulating materials. The interaction of light and matter is of fundamental importance in science and technology: it determines the characterization of materials through optical spectroscopy and forms the basis of photovoltaics as a renewable energy resource. The goal of this research is to develop theoretical and computational methods for light-matter interactions that are more accurate and efficient than existing approaches.

When light gets absorbed in a material, negatively charged electrons are excited into higher states, leaving behind them a positively charged void that is called a "hole" state. Electrons and holes can team up to form pairs, called excitons, which give rise to characteristic spectroscopic features and often dominate the optical properties of materials. The theoretical and computational description of excitonic effects is challenging, since the electron-hole pairs are formed within the original material and are subject to the influence of all other electrons therein.

This project will utilize a quantum-mechanical method called time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT), which has been very successful in describing the dynamics of interacting electronic systems in many areas in physics, chemistry, and materials science. Within this theoretical framework, the PI will develop new ways of accounting for the quantum behavior of many-electron systems, specifically focusing on properties that are necessary for the accurate description of excitons in optical spectroscopy. Another research goal will be to adapt a computer code called Qb@ll that is capable of describing the real-time dynamics of complex electronic systems, to account for excitonic properties, and use it to study the optical properties of materials with defects and interfaces.

The research activities will go hand-in-hand with educational efforts, consisting of training and mentoring of graduate students in theoretical and computational condensed-matter research, and the development of an online course in density-functional theory at the undergraduate and beginning-graduate level. Undergraduate students will be involved in the design and development of course materials and of hands-on computational exercises.

 
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division jointly fund this award on fundamental research and education to develop theoretical and computational methodology for the study of excitonic properties in semiconductors and insulators. Excitons dominate the optical properties of many materials in the spectral region around the absorption edge; they arise from the attractive screened interaction of electrons and holes created during optical excitations. At present, the Bethe-Salpeter equation is the standard method for calculating excitonic properties in solids, but at significant computational cost. The PI will develop and implement alternative approaches for excitons based on time-dependent density-functional theory (TDDFT).

The key challenge for TDDFT is to account for exchange and correlation (XC) effects via suitable approximations; the accurate description of excitonic properties requires XC functionals with the proper long-range behavior and with proper screening. The first goal in this project is to develop more accurate excitonic XC functionals for linear-response TDDFT, using three key ideas: simple parametrizations of the matrix form of long-range-corrected XC kernels, approximations derived from many-body theory, and nonlocal exchange screened with model dielectric functions. These models will be assessed by comparing calculated exciton binding energies and spectral strengths with experimental data.

The second goal is to adapt the Qb@ll computer code for exciton dynamics with the time-dependent Kohn-Sham equation for solids. Qb@ll is capable of massively parallel calculations with unit cells containing many atoms, which makes it suitable to treat complex systems. Applications to bound exciton complexes at defects and charge-transfer excitons in molecular crystals will be carried out. In addition, the Qb@ll code allows coupling of electronic and ionic degrees of freedom, which is key for describing relaxation and charge separation in photovoltaic processes from first principles.

The research activities will go hand-in-hand with educational efforts, consisting of training and mentoring of graduate students in theoretical and computational condensed-matter research, and the development of an online course in density-functional theory at the undergraduate and beginning-graduate level. Undergraduate students will be involved in the design and development of course materials and of hands-on computational exercises.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this project is based the development of novel methods for the theoretical and computational description of the interaction of light and matter. There are two major outcomes.

The first-principles calculation of the optical properties of insulating and semiconducting materials is an important task in electronic structure theory. The standard approach for the calculation of optical properties in insulating and semiconducting materials is known as the Bethe-Salpeter equation (BSE). The BSE is accurate but computationally expensive. In this project, we have developed an alternative approach for the optical spectra of materials based on time-dependent density-functional theory,  and have shown it to be as accurate as the BSE, but computationally cheaper.  Applications were carried out for many semiconducting and insulating materials (see Figure 1), including a new class of all-inorganic perovskites (Figure 2). This new approach will make it possible to predict the optical properties of complex and technologically important materials at a much lower computational cost than previously possible.

Excitons are a phenomenon in condensed matter which has attracted much recent scientific interest. Excitons are bound electron-hole pairs which dominate the optical properties of many insulators and semiconductors close to the absorption threshold. The formation and relaxation of excitons takes place on femtosecond time scales; the life cycle of excitons can be experimentally accessed using pump-probe and other techniques. We have developed a theoretical approach to study time-resolved exciton dynamics based on time-dependent density-functional theory, and applied it to solids with weakly and strongly bound excitons, including an all-inorganic perovskite (see Figure 3). This new approach will make it possible to simulate ultrafast exciton dynamics from first principles, including nonlinear effects, in a broad range of materials, and at a computational cost much lower than other many-body techniques.

The broader impact of this project is of an educational nature, focusing on the promotion of online education in density-functional theory (DFT) at the undergraduate and beginning graduate level. DFT is a methodology, based on quantum mechanics, which is used by many researchers worldwide to calculate the electronic and structural properties of materials. There is a great demand to train students in DFT, and online platforms can provide access to a very wide audience. The PI collaborated with researchers from the Ecole Polytechnique at Palaiseau, France, to develop an open online course in DFT (see Figure 4). During two visits in 2018 (July 17-31 and October 13-20), the PI recorded 6 short online lectures in video format, and contributed lecture notes and exercises. The course went live on the Coursera platform in 2020 (https://www.coursera.org/learn/density-functional-theory), and has since then attracted over 9000 learners. In addition, the PI has developed and taught a DFT course at the University of Missouri, which was offered partly online to undergraduate and beginning graduate students in 2020 and in 2021.
